keyTakeAways: Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man, was sentenced to five years to life in prison for rape charges stemming from incidents in northern Utah in 2008.
Rossi allegedly faked his death in 2020 after being identified via a DNA rape kit, and used aliases including Arthur Knight to evade capture.
He was arrested in Scotland in 2024 after being recognized by hospital staff through tattoos linked to an Interpol notice.
He previously was convicted of sex-related charges in Ohio in 2008 and is wanted in Rhode Island for failing to register as a sex offender.
The victim testified about being coerced into paying for dates, car repairs, and debts, and being raped in his apartment, leading to a conviction in August 2025.
Rossi maintained his innocence in court, claiming the women were lying, but was convicted by a jury.
Utah's legal system allows sentencing ranges, and in this case, five years to life is the full range for first-degree rape.
The case highlights the importance of addressing rape kit backlogs and using DNA evidence to identify and prosecute offenders who flee or disguise themselves.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Utah judge sentenced Nicholas Rossi, a 38-year-old man who faked his death in 2020 to evade rape charges, to a prison term ranging from five years to life. Rossi, who was identified through a DNA match from a decade-old rape kit, had previously been convicted of raping two women in northern Utah in 2008. He used aliases such as Arthur Knight and a false identity tied to Brown University to evade capture, and was arrested in Scotland in 2024 after being recognized by hospital staff through tattoos. The victim testified about being coerced into financial obligations and raped in his apartment, and the court found him guilty. Despite claiming innocence, Rossi was convicted, and the case underscores the importance of DNA backlog resolution and the dangers of flight by predators. Authorities from Rhode Island, Utah, and Scotland, along with the FBI, are involved in tracking and prosecuting him, reflecting broader efforts to combat sexual violence and offender evasion.
title: Man accused of faking his own death and fleeing the US after rape charges gets at least five years in prison
